elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two novel 3-D 4d-4f (Ln-Ag) coordination polymers based on double wave-like [Ln2Ag2IN4(OH)2] n  layers and two mixed ligands display the typical metal- and ligand-based luminescence emission.

Highlights

   ⋅ Two novel 3-D 4d-4f (Ln-Ag) coordination polymers have been hydrothermally assembled by two mixed ligands (HIN and     NO   3     -    ).   ⋅ Both 1 and 2 based on zigzag [Ln2] n  chains exhibit the first double wave-like [Ln2Ag2IN4(OH)2] n  layers.   ⋅ Compound 1 displays intensely red luminescence in solid state.

elements.clean_text:
Two novel 3-D 4d-4f (Ln-Ag) coordination polymers have been hydrothermally assembled by two mixed ligands (HIN and     NO   3     -    ).

Both 1 and 2 based on zigzag [Ln2] n  chains exhibit the first double wave-like [Ln2Ag2IN4(OH)2] n  layers.

Compound 1 displays intensely red luminescence in solid state.

Abstract

Two original three-dimensional (3-D) 4d-4f heterometallic coordination polymers, [Ln2Ag3(IN)5(OH)2(NO3)][NO3]⋅nH2O (Ln=Eu, n =2 (1); Ln=Ho, n =1 (2); HIN=isonicotinic acid), have been synthesized by hydrothermal assemble of Ln2O3 (Ln=Eu for 1; Ho for 2), HIN, AgNO3 and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). These two compounds show isostructural architectures and exhibit unusual 3-D open frameworks which are built upon the second ligand     NO   3     -     linking 2-D double wave-like [Ln2Ag2(IN)4(OH)2] n  layers and Ag(IN) subunits. 1-D channel is found in the framework. And the luminescent properties of the two compounds have also been investigated.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">During the past decades, more and more attentions have been focused on the design and preparation of lanthanide-transition metal (d–f) heterometallic coordination polymers for their impressive topological structures  and potentially interesting applications in magnetism , photochemical sensors , gas storage , ion-exchange , catalysis . Coordination preference of the metal ions plays a very important role in the construction of extended structures, which has been proved by a large amount of 3d–4f and 4d–4f heteronuclear coordination polymers with well-designed organic ligands . The synthesis of heteronuclear 3d–4f coordination polymers has become widespread over the recent years, but there are few reports on 4d–4f heteronuclear coordination polymers despite their potential application as luminescent materials .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the past decades, more and more attentions have been focused on the design and preparation of lanthanide-transition metal (d-f) heterometallic coordination polymers for their impressive topological structures  and potentially interesting applications in magnetism , photochemical sensors , gas storage , ion-exchange , catalysis . Coordination preference of the metal ions plays a very important role in the construction of extended structures, which has been proved by a large amount of 3d-4f and 4d-4f heteronuclear coordination polymers with well-designed organic ligands . The synthesis of heteronuclear 3d-4f coordination polymers has become widespread over the recent years, but there are few reports on 4d-4f heteronuclear coordination polymers despite their potential application as luminescent materials .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">As is known to all that lanthanide and silver ions have different appetency for O and N donors. Generally, the lanthanides are relatively easy to coordinate with the O-donor ligands to form lanthanide-carboxylate coordination polymers . The soft Ag(I) ion has a strong tendency to bond to N-donor ligands with linear, trigonal, and tetrahedral coordination mode, being favorable building blocks for constructing of coordination polymers. Thus, if a ligand contains both N-donor and O-donor atoms, such as pyridine-carboxylate , iminodiacetic acid , and glycine , Ag(I) ion could be introduced to link the lanthanide-carboxylate subunits. If these two different kinds of coordination polymers could be combined into one framework, then, they may show attractive structures and excellent properties. To realize this self-assembly, how to harmonize the relationship between the two kind of metal-organic building units when they are integrated into one coordination compound must be solved. One unexceptionable method is to choose multifunctional ligands which have special orientation of donor atoms and proper rigidity with two kinds of coordination sites (O/N and flexibility are the most important factor to achieve this goal). As a multifunctional rigid ligand, isonicotinate acid (HIN), which can cause efficient transfer energy to lanthanide ions , fits all the conditions. But as the presence of the space restriction within terminal HIN ligand restrain further connection, most Ln–IN–Ag compounds present one-dimension or two-dimension coordination frameworks with just one ligand. For example, Han has successfully synthesized three 1-D isostructural heterometallic coordination polymers, [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(ina)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>][NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O [Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Sm (1), Eu (2), Dy (3) and Hina<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>isonicotinic acid]. These three complexes consist of extended 1-D zigzag chains structure built upon [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(ina)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>] subunits connected by Ag–Ag interactions . Cai obtained two 2-D coordination polymers, {[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ln(IN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Sm and Eu, IN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>isonicotinate), which are built up from elliptical triple-deck cylinders hinged by <ce:italic>meso</ce:italic>-helical chains containing an isonicotinate ligand , etc. But the report about high-dimensional 4d–4f coordination polymers is relatively less. So the assemble of novel 3-D 4d–4f coordination polymers is still a huge challenge.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As is known to all that lanthanide and silver ions have different appetency for O and N donors. Generally, the lanthanides are relatively easy to coordinate with the O-donor ligands to form lanthanide-carboxylate coordination polymers . The soft Ag(I) ion has a strong tendency to bond to N-donor ligands with linear, trigonal, and tetrahedral coordination mode, being favorable building blocks for constructing of coordination polymers. Thus, if a ligand contains both N-donor and O-donor atoms, such as pyridine-carboxylate , iminodiacetic acid , and glycine , Ag(I) ion could be introduced to link the lanthanide-carboxylate subunits. If these two different kinds of coordination polymers could be combined into one framework, then, they may show attractive structures and excellent properties. To realize this self-assembly, how to harmonize the relationship between the two kind of metal-organic building units when they are integrated into one coordination compound must be solved. One unexceptionable method is to choose multifunctional ligands which have special orientation of donor atoms and proper rigidity with two kinds of coordination sites (O/N and flexibility are the most important factor to achieve this goal). As a multifunctional rigid ligand, isonicotinate acid (HIN), which can cause efficient transfer energy to lanthanide ions , fits all the conditions. But as the presence of the space restriction within terminal HIN ligand restrain further connection, most Ln-IN-Ag compounds present one-dimension or two-dimension coordination frameworks with just one ligand. For example, Han has successfully synthesized three 1-D isostructural heterometallic coordination polymers, [Ln2Ag4(ina)8(H2O)10][NO3]2⋅4H2O [Ln=Sm (1), Eu (2), Dy (3) and Hina=isonicotinic acid]. These three complexes consist of extended 1-D zigzag chains structure built upon [Sm2Ag4(ina)8(H2O)10] subunits connected by Ag-Ag interactions . Cai obtained two 2-D coordination polymers, {[Ag2Ln(IN)4(H2O)2]⋅(NO3)⋅(H2O)} n  (Ln=Sm and Eu, IN- =isonicotinate), which are built up from elliptical triple-deck cylinders hinged by meso-helical chains containing an isonicotinate ligand , etc. But the report about high-dimensional 4d-4f coordination polymers is relatively less. So the assemble of novel 3-D 4d-4f coordination polymers is still a huge challenge.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">More recently, original 3-D 4d–4f frameworks were obtained by the introduction of a second small ligand, such as oxalic acid, racemic lactic acid, terephthalic acid, etc , which interacts with the first one. Based on the trying of employing two mixed ligands, a series of 3-D 4d–4f coordination polymers have been synthesized. To the best of our knowledge, the reported articles about 3-D 4d–4f polymers with nitric acid and isonicotinic acid as ligands are relatively rare. Herein, we report two new 3-D 4d–4f open framework coordination polymers [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(IN)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)][NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O [Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Eu, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text: More recently, original 3-D 4d-4f frameworks were obtained by the introduction of a second small ligand, such as oxalic acid, racemic lactic acid, terephthalic acid, etc , which interacts with the first one. Based on the trying of employing two mixed ligands, a series of 3-D 4d-4f coordination polymers have been synthesized. To the best of our knowledge, the reported articles about 3-D 4d-4f polymers with nitric acid and isonicotinic acid as ligands are relatively rare. Herein, we report two new 3-D 4d-4f open framework coordination polymers [Ln2Ag3(IN)5(OH)2(NO3)][NO3]⋅nH2O [Ln=Eu, n =2 (1); Ln=Ho, n =1 (2)] constructed by double wave-like [Ln2Ag2IN4(OH)2] n  layers and Ag(IN) subunits with the second ligand     NO   3     -     linked them tighter. Free     NO   3     -     groups and water molecules are filled in the channels of compound 1 and 2. Compared with our group' reported 4d-4f coordination polymers , we find that this is the first time     NO   3     -     group connects with Ag+ ions.

IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer using KBr pellets in the 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> region. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were measured on a FP-6500 spectrofluorimeter equipped with a 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>W xenon lamp as the excitation source.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Material and physical measurements

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffracation (PXRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker D8X diffractometer epuipped with monochromatized Cu Kα radiation(λ =0.15418nm) at room temperature. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer using KBr pellets in the 4000-400cm-1 region. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in a N2 atmosphere on a Diamond thermogravimetric analyzer from 50 to 1100°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra of 1 and 2 were measured on a FP-6500 spectrofluorimeter equipped with a 450W xenon lamp as the excitation source.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st020">Synthesis of complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st025">[Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(IN)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)][NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">A mixture of Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (185.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.528<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HIN (245.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 2.00<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (44.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.259<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HCOOH (88%, 18.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COOH (99.5%, 220<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1.86<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HF (40%, 43<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 8.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (8.00<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), which was stirred for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at room temperature. And then, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 2.5 with HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (50%). Finally, it was sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for seven days. Small rectangular colorless strip crystals of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained after cooling to the room temperature and washing with distilled water (193.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.135<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, yield of 25.59% based on Eu). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc for C<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>: C, 25.14; H, 1.82; N, 6.84. Found: C, 25.03; H, 1.95; N, 6.70%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>): 3440 br, 1596 s, 1545 s, 1415 m, 768 m, 692 m, 556 m, 440 m.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complexes

[Eu2Ag3(IN)5(OH)2(NO3)][NO3]⋅2H2O (1)

A mixture of Eu2O3 (185.8mg, 0.528mmol), HIN (245.4mg, 2.00mmol), AgNO3 (44.4mg, 0.259mmol), HCOOH (88%, 18.6mg, 0.36mmol), CH3COOH (99.5%, 220mg, 1.86mmol), HF (40%, 43mg, 8.6mmol), and H2O (8.00mL), which was stirred for 12h at room temperature. And then, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 2.5 with HNO3 (50%). Finally, it was sealed in a 25ml Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 170°C for seven days. Small rectangular colorless strip crystals of compound 1 were obtained after cooling to the room temperature and washing with distilled water (193.5mg, 0.135mmol, yield of 25.59% based on Eu). Anal. Calc for C30H26Ag3Eu2N7O20: C, 25.14; H, 1.82; N, 6.84. Found: C, 25.03; H, 1.95; N, 6.70%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3440 br, 1596 s, 1545 s, 1415 m, 768 m, 692 m, 556 m, 440 m.

When the Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was replaced by Ho<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (186.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.484<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), the small rectangular dark yellow strip crystals of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were received (107.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.0745<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol yield of 15.39% based on Ho). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc for C<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ho<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>: C, 25.00; H, 1.67; N, 6.81. Found: C, 25.03; H, 2.15; N, 7.00%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>): 3443 br, 1592 s, 1544 s, 1418 m, 772 m, 693 m, 563 m, 443 m.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
[Ho2Ag3(IN)5(OH)2(NO3)][NO3]⋅H2O (2)

A similar manner has been carried out to the synthesis of 2. When the Eu2O3 was replaced by Ho2O3 (186.7mg, 0.484mmol), the small rectangular dark yellow strip crystals of compound 2 were received (107.3mg, 0.0745mmol yield of 15.39% based on Ho). Anal. Calc for C30H24Ag3Ho2N7O19: C, 25.00; H, 1.67; N, 6.81. Found: C, 25.03; H, 2.15; N, 7.00%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3443 br, 1592 s, 1544 s, 1418 m, 772 m, 693 m, 563 m, 443 m.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st035">X-ray data collection and structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Single-crystal structure determination was performed on a Bruker SMART APEX2 CCD diffractometer at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and a sealed tube X-ray source (Mo Kα radiation, <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) operating at 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV and 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mA. Both structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were solved by direct methods and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by full-matrix least-squares methods using the <ce:small-caps>shelx</ce:small-caps>97 program package. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms of water for both structures were not located, while the H atoms of the organic moieties were included in calculated positions, assigned isotropic displacement parameters, and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. Ag(2), Ag(2a), Ag(3), Ag(3a) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are disordered with the occupied factors of 0.5. O(1w), O(1wa), O(14), O(14a), O(15), O(15a), O(16), and O(16a) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are also disordered with each site being opportunely half occupied. A summary of the crystallographic data and structural determination for both compounds is provided in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and angles were listed in . And hydrogen bond dates were listed in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray data collection and structure determination

Single-crystal structure determination was performed on a Bruker SMART APEX2 CCD diffractometer at 293K and a sealed tube X-ray source (Mo Kα radiation, λ =0.71073Å) operating at 50kV and 30mA. Both structures 1 and 2 were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the shelx97 program package. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms of water for both structures were not located, while the H atoms of the organic moieties were included in calculated positions, assigned isotropic displacement parameters, and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. Ag(2), Ag(2a), Ag(3), Ag(3a) for 1 and 2 are disordered with the occupied factors of 0.5. O(1w), O(1wa), O(14), O(14a), O(15), O(15a), O(16), and O(16a) for 2 are also disordered with each site being opportunely half occupied. A summary of the crystallographic data and structural determination for both compounds is provided in  . Selected bond lengths and angles were listed in . And hydrogen bond dates were listed in .

The difference in reflection intensities of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are probably due to the preferred orientation effect of the powder sample.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray powder diffraction

The experimental and simulated XRD patterns of compounds 1 and 2 are presented in , the experimental peak positions are in agreement with simulated XRD pattern, which indicates the phase purity of both compounds. The difference in reflection intensities of 1 and 2 are probably due to the preferred orientation effect of the powder sample.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis

The hydrothermal assemble of Ln2O3 (Ln=Eu 1; Ho 2), HIN, AgNO3, and so on in an aqueous solution at 170°C for 7days produced rectangular crystals. As is well known, a lot of factors, such as initial reagents, temperature, pH values, and reaction time, can influence the final crystals . During our research, we find that the initial reagents were crucial in the synthesis. In our previous work, we tried to use HCOOH as the second ligand, but it is always oxidized to     CO   3     2 -    , two 2D coordination polymers constructed by interesting flat lanthanide carbonate layers, [Ln(IN)(CO3)(H2O)] (Ln=La and Eu)  were made. When we used CH3COOH as the second ligand, three Ln-Ag coordination compounds, [La2Ag3(IN)6(OAc)(H2O)3][NO3]2⋅2H2O (HOAc=acetic acid) and [LnAg2(IN)4(OAc)⋅5H2O]⋅2H2O (Ln=Gd and Eu), were obtained . And when we employed two mixed ligands HCOOH and CH3COOH, as the second ligands, two nanosized huge Ln26 (Ln=Dy and Gd) spherical clusters, Zn1.5Dy26(IN)25(CH3COO)8(CO3)11(OH)26(H2O)29 and Zn1.5Gd26(IN)26(CH3COO)7(CO3)11(OH)26(H2O)28 were synthetized . As a continuous work, now we are attempting to add X- (F-, Cl-, Br-, I-) to the previous reaction systems. A 2-D high-nuclearity pure Ho48 cluster owning waist-drum-like structure K2[Ho48(IN)46(μ3-OH)84(μ4-OH)4(μ5-O)2(OAc)4(H2O)14(CO3)Br2]⋅2HIN⋅20H2O  has been obtained. While we added HF to the previous reaction systems, compound 1 and 2 were obtained, maybe for that F- controls the rate of hydrolysis of rare earth ions. Therefore, although HCOOH, CH3COOH and HF were not included in the final products, they are necessary to for the preparation of 1 and 2. and at the same time, they can keep the pH value of the reaction systems. Without any one of them, compound 1 and 2 can not be obtained. In addition, there are no crystals could be obtained when we use other rare earth oxides to replace Eu2O3 and Ho2O3 in many kinds of reaction conditions, such as, we tried to use different pH values, for example, 1.5, 2.0 and 3.0, and different reaction time, such as 5, 6, and 8 d, to synthesize, but only powder were received. And we didn't obtain crystals while performed the reaction at a lower or higher temperature, for example, 100, 150, 160, and 180°C. Maybe for that the reaction system is very sensitive to initial reagents, temperature, pH values, and reaction time.

elements.clean_text:
Structural descriptions of complexes

[Eu2Ag3(IN)5(OH)2(NO3)][NO3]⋅2H2O (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of the two compounds reveal that they are in the low-symmetry triclinic space group   P   1   ¯     and are of isostructural architecture. Thus, only the structure of complex 1 is described in details as the representation. As shown in  (a), the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of two crystallographic independent Eu3+ ions, three Ag+ ions, five IN- ligands, two μ3-OH, two     NO   3     -     ions as well as two water molecules. Both Eu(1) and Eu(2) are eight-coordinated, they employ distorted square antiprism coordination geometry accomplished by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from five IN- bridging ligands and three oxygen atoms from three μ3-OH ((b) and (c)). The Eu-O bond lengths range from 2.297(4) to 2.464(4)Å, the O-Eu-O bond angles vary from 66.3(9) to 153.0(1)°, which are in a reasonable scope compared with reported lanthanide complexes . In compound 1, there are three different coordination models for Ag(I). Ag(1) is coordinated in a linear fashion by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of the IN- ligands. The N-Ag-N bond angle is 177.6(1)°; Ag(2) is surrounded by a N atom from IN- ligand and one O atom from     NO   3     -     with the N-Ag-O bond angle of 152.3(2)°; Ag(3) adopts trigonal geometry, coordinated by two N atoms from IN- ligands and one O atom from     NO   3     -    . The Ag-O bond lengths range from 2.400(8) to 2.566(1)Å and the Ag-N bond length varys from 2.138(6) to 2.375(4)Å. The N-Ag-N bond angles vary from 150.3(2)° to 177.6(2)°. All the bond lengths and angles are in agreement with the reported compounds .

Adjacent [Eu2] units are linked with each other to form a zigzag [Eu2] n  chain along c axis, as revealed in  (a), which is quite rare in 4d-4f coordination polymers. Ag(1) is connected by N(2) and N(5) from IN- ligands to form an pillared IN-Ag-IN linker (building unit A). Besides, building unit B is produced by Ag(3) and IN- ligands in similar way. Zigzag [Eu2] n  chains are further linked by the two types of building units to form an interesting double wave-like [Eu2Ag2IN4(OH)2] n  layer along a axis ((b)). Then, neighbouring double wave-like [Eu2Ag2IN4(OH)2] n  layers are connected by Ag(2) and second ligand     NO   3     -     to form a 3-D open framework ((c)). To the best of our kownledge,the numbers of 3-D 4d-4f coordination polymers constructed by mixed ligands are limited, and what's more, the second ligand     NO   3     -     group connected with 4d metal is relatively rare in 4d-4f complexes.

The distances between neighboring Ag+ vary from 3.211(2) to 3.256(1)Å, which are similar to the reported Ln-Ag complexes. It should be pointed that the second ligands     NO   3     -     play very important roles to the final structures of compound 1, some act as bridging ligand to connect Ag(I) and other free     NO   3     -     ions are inserted in the channel of the 3-D open framework with Ag⋯O interactions ( ) to keep charge balance. Interestingly, a 36-membered ring (36 MR) channel (9.1×8.5nm) composed of 2 Eu, 16 C, 8 O, 6 N and 4 Ag atoms is found in compound 1 As far as we know, similar 36 MRs have not been reported previously in 4d-4f coordination polymers. Small water clusters (H2O)2 are filled in the channels ( ). The distance between O(1w) and O(2w) is about 2.81(2)Å.

[Ho2Ag3(IN)5(OH)2(NO3)][NO3]⋅H2O (2)

The structure of 2 is quite the same as 1 except that there is only one free water molecule in the 1-D channels (9.0×4.8nm) ( ). We thought the cause might be the decreasing of the lanthanide ions radius which leads to the reducing of the channels size .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st070">IR spectra and TG analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The IR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are similar, as shown in , the strong band around 3433<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be ascribed to the O–H stretching vibration of the water molecular. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the characteristic bands of carboxylate groups are shown at 1592–1596<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for asymmetric stretching and 1415–1418<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for symmetric stretching. Typically sharp peaks in the range of 768–440<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are associated with the ν(Eu–O) or ν(Ho–O) and ν(Ag–N).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
IR spectra and TG analysis

The IR spectra of 1 and 2 are similar, as shown in , the strong band around 3433cm-1 in 1 and 2 can be ascribed to the O-H stretching vibration of the water molecular. For 1 and 2, the characteristic bands of carboxylate groups are shown at 1592-1596cm-1 for asymmetric stretching and 1415-1418cm-1 for symmetric stretching. Typically sharp peaks in the range of 768-440cm-1 are associated with the ν(Eu-O) or ν(Ho-O) and ν(Ag-N).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The thermogravimetric curves (TGA) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are shown in . Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> lost lattice water and coordination water molecules (observed 4.04%, 3.78% calculated) in the range of 30–210<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The weight loss beginning at 320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C could be attributed to the vaporization of HIN resulting structure decomposition. The TGA of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> from 30 to 1100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is quite the same as that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. It started to lose weight from 30 to 198<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with a loss of 2.79%, which could be contributed to the loss of lattice water and coordination water molecules (calculated 2.50%). It lost 45.47% of its total weight continuously starting from 198 to 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which belongs to the evaporation of HIN (47.12% calculated) as a result of framework collapses. Both TGA profiles resemble those of other reported 4d–4f coordination polymers .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The thermogravimetric curves (TGA) of 1 and 2 are shown in . Compound 1 lost lattice water and coordination water molecules (observed 4.04%, 3.78% calculated) in the range of 30-210°C. The weight loss beginning at 320°C could be attributed to the vaporization of HIN resulting structure decomposition. The TGA of compound 2 from 30 to 1100°C is quite the same as that of 1. It started to lose weight from 30 to 198°C, with a loss of 2.79%, which could be contributed to the loss of lattice water and coordination water molecules (calculated 2.50%). It lost 45.47% of its total weight continuously starting from 198 to 1000°C, which belongs to the evaporation of HIN (47.12% calculated) as a result of framework collapses. Both TGA profiles resemble those of other reported 4d-4f coordination polymers .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st075">Photoluminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The photoluminescent spectra of solid state samples <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at room temperature are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>. The blue fluorescence for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be observed, where the maximum emission wavelength is at 361<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Correspondingly, the peak with the maximum excited light at ca. 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm can be observed in the excitation spectra<ce:bold>,</ce:bold> which can boil down to ligand–ligand (IN–IN) interactions. The centroid distance between two interacting IN ligands is about 3.4556(82)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. As known to all, the free HIN displays a feeble emission peak at 431<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm while excited at 330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm in the ultraviolet (UV) region, so the fluorescence efficiency of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has been enhanced. We can attribute this to the IN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands’ attachment with Ho(III) and Ag(I) ions which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligands and reduce the energy loss of radiation thermal vibration. The energy differences in Ag and Ho ions caused by the coordination environment make the blue shift of the emission from UV light to the blue color region. It’s important to note that some reported articles show the emission spectrum of the Ag–Ag interaction  within 520–550<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. In addition, direct Ag–Ag interactions may be a very significant factor in the fluorescence properties of d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal coordination complexes . However, we do not observe emission peak of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at this range.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence properties

The photoluminescent spectra of solid state samples 1 and 2 at room temperature are shown in  . The blue fluorescence for 2 can be observed, where the maximum emission wavelength is at 361nm. Correspondingly, the peak with the maximum excited light at ca. 340nm can be observed in the excitation spectra, which can boil down to ligand-ligand (IN-IN) interactions. The centroid distance between two interacting IN ligands is about 3.4556(82)Å. As known to all, the free HIN displays a feeble emission peak at 431nm while excited at 330nm in the ultraviolet (UV) region, so the fluorescence efficiency of 2 has been enhanced. We can attribute this to the IN- ligands' attachment with Ho(III) and Ag(I) ions which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligands and reduce the energy loss of radiation thermal vibration. The energy differences in Ag and Ho ions caused by the coordination environment make the blue shift of the emission from UV light to the blue color region. It's important to note that some reported articles show the emission spectrum of the Ag-Ag interaction  within 520-550nm. In addition, direct Ag-Ag interactions may be a very significant factor in the fluorescence properties of d10 metal coordination complexes . However, we do not observe emission peak of 2 at this range.

elements.clean_text: The solid-state excitation spectrum of 1 is very different from 2 owing to the wonderful luminescent properties of Eu3+ ions, as shown in  . It shows strong excitation in 391nm, which corresponding to the transition absorption from ground state to excited state 5L6 of Eu3+, whose excited apexes corresponding to f-f transition of Eu3+ ions. The emission spectrum for Eu-containing consists of four bands located at about 592, 615, 653 and 700nm. The four main peaks can be ascribed to the 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3 and 5D0 → 7F4 transitions , respectively, The emission peak of ligands in compound 1 is not observed, which imply businesslike energy transfer from HIN ligand to metal . The dominated red emission of 5D0 → 7F2 transition is the most intense, which suggests that the HIN ligands are suitable for enhancing red luminescence of Eu(III) ions through efficient energy transfer from HIN ligand to lanthanide . The emission summit 5D0 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F4 correspond to a magnetic dipole transition with medium-strong intensities. It's strength should vary with the crystal field intensity acting on the Eu(III) ion. The emission peak 5D0 → 7F2 transition, on the other hand, is an electric dipole transition and is extremely sensitive to chemical bonds in the vicinity of Eu3+, and its emission is the so-called hypersensitive transition responsible for the brilliant-red emission of 1, whose intensity extremely increased due to the site symmetry of Eu(III) ions decreases . The intensity(I) sequence of the summits falls in the order I(5D0 → 7F2)> I(5D0 → 7F1)> I(5D0 → 7F4)→ I(5D0 → 7F3). The intensity ratio of I(5D0 → 7F2)/I(5D0 → 7F1) is about 3.16 which shows that an efficient energy transfer from organic ligands to the metal ion (LMCT) . What's more, Eu(III) has the lower symmetric coordination environment in 1. Compared with the luminescence of reported 1D or 2D Eu-Ag coordination polymers constructed from HIN/isonicotinic acid with similar coordination environments , we can find that the intensity ratio of I(5D0 → 7F2)/I(5D0 → 7F1) for 3D Eu-Ag coordination polymers are the highest maybe for that Eu3+ in 3D Eu-Ag coordination polymers occupy sites with the lowest symmetry and the most efficient energy transfer from LMCT. In addition, the absence of other emission peaks in the emission spectrum illustrates that ligand-to-Ag charge transition is ineffective. This is in good agreement with the result of the single-crystal X-ray analysis.

<ce:section-title id="st080">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">In summary, two novel 3-D 4d–4f (Ln–Ag) heteronuclear coordination polymers based on double wave-like [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>IN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> layers and two mixed ligands displaying the typical metal- and ligand-based luminescence emission have been hydrothermally synthesized. Both of the two ligands contribute significantly to the successfully preparation of these two compound. We believe that the synthetic strategy for preparing 4d–4f heteronuclear coordination polymers would lead to more new lanthanide-transition metal heteronuclear coordination polymers with particular functions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, two novel 3-D 4d-4f (Ln-Ag) heteronuclear coordination polymers based on double wave-like [Ln2Ag2IN4(OH)2] n  layers and two mixed ligands displaying the typical metal- and ligand-based luminescence emission have been hydrothermally synthesized. Both of the two ligands contribute significantly to the successfully preparation of these two compound. We believe that the synthetic strategy for preparing 4d-4f heteronuclear coordination polymers would lead to more new lanthanide-transition metal heteronuclear coordination polymers with particular functions.

And then, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 2.5 with HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (50%). Finally, it was sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for seven days. Small rectangular colorless strip crystals of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained after cooling to the room temperature and washing with distilled water (193.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.135<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, yield of 25.59% based on Eu). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc for C<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>: C, 25.14; H, 1.82; N, 6.84. Found: C, 25.03; H, 1.95; N, 6.70%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>): 3440 br, 1596 s, 1545 s, 1415 m, 768 m, 692 m, 556 m, 440 m.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st030">[Ho<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(IN)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)][NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">A similar manner has been carried out to the synthesis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. When the Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was replaced by Ho<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (186.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.484<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), the small rectangular dark yellow strip crystals of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were received (107.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.0745<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol yield of 15.39% based on Ho). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc for C<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ho<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>: C, 25.00; H, 1.67; N, 6.81. Found: C, 25.03; H, 2.15; N, 7.00%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>): 3443 br, 1592 s, 1544 s, 1418 m, 772 m, 693 m, 563 m, 443 m.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complexes

[Eu2Ag3(IN)5(OH)2(NO3)][NO3]⋅2H2O (1)

A mixture of Eu2O3 (185.8mg, 0.528mmol), HIN (245.4mg, 2.00mmol), AgNO3 (44.4mg, 0.259mmol), HCOOH (88%, 18.6mg, 0.36mmol), CH3COOH (99.5%, 220mg, 1.86mmol), HF (40%, 43mg, 8.6mmol), and H2O (8.00mL), which was stirred for 12h at room temperature. And then, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 2.5 with HNO3 (50%). Finally, it was sealed in a 25ml Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 170°C for seven days. Small rectangular colorless strip crystals of compound 1 were obtained after cooling to the room temperature and washing with distilled water (193.5mg, 0.135mmol, yield of 25.59% based on Eu). Anal. Calc for C30H26Ag3Eu2N7O20: C, 25.14; H, 1.82; N, 6.84. Found: C, 25.03; H, 1.95; N, 6.70%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3440 br, 1596 s, 1545 s, 1415 m, 768 m, 692 m, 556 m, 440 m.

[Ho2Ag3(IN)5(OH)2(NO3)][NO3]⋅H2O (2)

A similar manner has been carried out to the synthesis of 2. When the Eu2O3 was replaced by Ho2O3 (186.7mg, 0.484mmol), the small rectangular dark yellow strip crystals of compound 2 were received (107.3mg, 0.0745mmol yield of 15.39% based on Ho). Anal. Calc for C30H24Ag3Ho2N7O19: C, 25.00; H, 1.67; N, 6.81. Found: C, 25.03; H, 2.15; N, 7.00%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3443 br, 1592 s, 1544 s, 1418 m, 772 m, 693 m, 563 m, 443 m.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Structural descriptions of complexes

[Eu2Ag3(IN)5(OH)2(NO3)][NO3]⋅2H2O (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of the two compounds reveal that they are in the low-symmetry triclinic space group   P   1   ¯     and are of isostructural architecture. Thus, only the structure of complex 1 is described in details as the representation. As shown in  (a), the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of two crystallographic independent Eu3+ ions, three Ag+ ions, five IN- ligands, two μ3-OH, two     NO   3     -     ions as well as two water molecules. Both Eu(1) and Eu(2) are eight-coordinated, they employ distorted square antiprism coordination geometry accomplished by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from five IN- bridging ligands and three oxygen atoms from three μ3-OH ((b) and (c)). The Eu-O bond lengths range from 2.297(4) to 2.464(4)Å, the O-Eu-O bond angles vary from 66.3(9) to 153.0(1)°, which are in a reasonable scope compared with reported lanthanide complexes . In compound 1, there are three different coordination models for Ag(I). Ag(1) is coordinated in a linear fashion by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of the IN- ligands. The N-Ag-N bond angle is 177.6(1)°; Ag(2) is surrounded by a N atom from IN- ligand and one O atom from     NO   3     -     with the N-Ag-O bond angle of 152.3(2)°; Ag(3) adopts trigonal geometry, coordinated by two N atoms from IN- ligands and one O atom from     NO   3     -    . The Ag-O bond lengths range from 2.400(8) to 2.566(1)Å and the Ag-N bond length varys from 2.138(6) to 2.375(4)Å. The N-Ag-N bond angles vary from 150.3(2)° to 177.6(2)°. All the bond lengths and angles are in agreement with the reported compounds .

Eu(III) ion and IN- ligand combine together to form a relative flat Eu-IN layer along a axis. As the flat Eu-IN layers provide active nitrogen atoms to the affinity for Ag(I) ions, a wavy Ag+ layer is inserted between the Eu-IN layers ( (a)). To the best of our knowledge, this wavy "Ag layer", as shown in (b), was very scarce in the reported 4d-4f Ln-Ag compounds. The distances between neighboring Ag+ vary from 3.211(2) to 3.256(1)Å, which are similar to the reported Ln-Ag complexes. It should be pointed that the second ligands     NO   3     -     play very important roles to the final structures of compound 1, some act as bridging ligand to connect Ag(I) and other free     NO   3     -     ions are inserted in the channel of the 3-D open framework with Ag⋯O interactions ( ) to keep charge balance. Interestingly, a 36-membered ring (36 MR) channel (9.1×8.5nm) composed of 2 Eu, 16 C, 8 O, 6 N and 4 Ag atoms is found in compound 1 As far as we know, similar 36 MRs have not been reported previously in 4d-4f coordination polymers. Small water clusters (H2O)2 are filled in the channels ( ). The distance between O(1w) and O(2w) is about 2.81(2)Å.

The thermogravimetric curves (TGA) of 1 and 2 are shown in . Compound 1 lost lattice water and coordination water molecules (observed 4.04%, 3.78% calculated) in the range of 30-210°C. The weight loss beginning at 320°C could be attributed to the vaporization of HIN resulting structure decomposition. The TGA of compound 2 from 30 to 1100°C is quite the same as that of 1. It started to lose weight from 30 to 198°C, with a loss of 2.79%, which could be contributed to the loss of lattice water and coordination water molecules (calculated 2.50%). It lost 45.47% of its total weight continuously starting from 198 to 1000°C, which belongs to the evaporation of HIN (47.12% calculated) as a result of framework collapses. Both TGA profiles resemble those of other reported 4d-4f coordination polymers .

Photoluminescence properties

The photoluminescent spectra of solid state samples 1 and 2 at room temperature are shown in  . The blue fluorescence for 2 can be observed, where the maximum emission wavelength is at 361nm. Correspondingly, the peak with the maximum excited light at ca. 340nm can be observed in the excitation spectra, which can boil down to ligand-ligand (IN-IN) interactions. The centroid distance between two interacting IN ligands is about 3.4556(82)Å. As known to all, the free HIN displays a feeble emission peak at 431nm while excited at 330nm in the ultraviolet (UV) region, so the fluorescence efficiency of 2 has been enhanced. We can attribute this to the IN- ligands' attachment with Ho(III) and Ag(I) ions which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligands and reduce the energy loss of radiation thermal vibration. The energy differences in Ag and Ho ions caused by the coordination environment make the blue shift of the emission from UV light to the blue color region. It's important to note that some reported articles show the emission spectrum of the Ag-Ag interaction  within 520-550nm. In addition, direct Ag-Ag interactions may be a very significant factor in the fluorescence properties of d10 metal coordination complexes . However, we do not observe emission peak of 2 at this range.

decomposition temperature.type: loss of lattice water and coordination water molecules
vaporization of HIN resulting structure decomposition

cln_elements.clean_text: The solid-state excitation spectrum of 1 is very different from 2 owing to the wonderful luminescent properties of Eu3+ ions, as shown in  . It shows strong excitation in 391nm, which corresponding to the transition absorption from ground state to excited state 5L6 of Eu3+, whose excited apexes corresponding to f-f transition of Eu3+ ions. The emission spectrum for Eu-containing consists of four bands located at about 592, 615, 653 and 700nm. The four main peaks can be ascribed to the 5D0 → 7F1, 5D0 → 7F2, 5D0 → 7F3 and 5D0 → 7F4 transitions , respectively, The emission peak of ligands in compound 1 is not observed, which imply businesslike energy transfer from HIN ligand to metal . The dominated red emission of 5D0 → 7F2 transition is the most intense, which suggests that the HIN ligands are suitable for enhancing red luminescence of Eu(III) ions through efficient energy transfer from HIN ligand to lanthanide . The emission summit 5D0 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F4 correspond to a magnetic dipole transition with medium-strong intensities. It's strength should vary with the crystal field intensity acting on the Eu(III) ion. The emission peak 5D0 → 7F2 transition, on the other hand, is an electric dipole transition and is extremely sensitive to chemical bonds in the vicinity of Eu3+, and its emission is the so-called hypersensitive transition responsible for the brilliant-red emission of 1, whose intensity extremely increased due to the site symmetry of Eu(III) ions decreases . The intensity(I) sequence of the summits falls in the order I(5D0 → 7F2)> I(5D0 → 7F1)> I(5D0 → 7F4)→ I(5D0 → 7F3). The intensity ratio of I(5D0 → 7F2)/I(5D0 → 7F1) is about 3.16 which shows that an efficient energy transfer from organic ligands to the metal ion (LMCT) . What's more, Eu(III) has the lower symmetric coordination environment in 1. Compared with the luminescence of reported 1D or 2D Eu-Ag coordination polymers constructed from HIN/isonicotinic acid with similar coordination environments , we can find that the intensity ratio of I(5D0 → 7F2)/I(5D0 → 7F1) for 3D Eu-Ag coordination polymers are the highest maybe for that Eu3+ in 3D Eu-Ag coordination polymers occupy sites with the lowest symmetry and the most efficient energy transfer from LMCT. In addition, the absence of other emission peaks in the emission spectrum illustrates that ligand-to-Ag charge transition is ineffective. This is in good agreement with the result of the single-crystal X-ray analysis.

Synthesis, structure characterization, and luminescent properties of two novel three-dimensional 4d–4f Ln–Ag coordination polymers based on two mixed ligands and zigzag [Ln2]
                  n
                chains (Ln=Eu and Ho)
